etymologies: late Middle English. From (i) Anglo-Norman and Middle French custode guardian, custodian

definitions: In the Franciscan order of friars: a guardian or warden of a house or of a subdivision of a province. Now somewhat rare (chiefly historical).

etymologies: late 18th century; earliest use found in Mary Berry (1763–1852), author. From Italian custode custode

definitions: In Italian contexts: a guardian, a custodian, especially of a public building.

notes.text: Sometimes difficult to distinguish from custode: see note there.
